{{Use mdy dates|date=January 2016}} {{Infobox news event | title = Shooting of Samuel DuBose | image =<!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:Samuel DuBose.jpg|frameless|center|upright]] --> | caption = Samuel DuBose | location = [[Cincinnati, Ohio]], U.S. | coordinates = {{coord|39.12322|-84.51319|region:US-OH_type:event|display=inline,title}} | date = {{start date|2015|07|19}} | time = 6:30 p.m. [[Eastern Time Zone|EDT]] | deaths = Samuel DuBose | accused = Raymond Tensing | filmed_by = Tensing's [[bodycam]] | charges = Murder, [[voluntary manslaughter]] }} On July 19, 2015, in [[Cincinnati, Ohio]], '''Samuel DuBose''', an unarmed man, was fatally shot by Ray Tensing, a [[University of Cincinnati]] police officer, during a [[traffic stop]] for a missing front license plate and a suspended driver's license. Tensing fired after DuBose started his car. Tensing stated that DuBose had begun to drive off and that he was being dragged because his arm was caught in the car. Prosecutors alleged that footage from Tensing's [[bodycam]] showed that he was not dragged, and a [[grand jury]] [[indicted]] him on charges of murder and voluntary manslaughter. He was then fired from the police department. He was released on bond before trial. A November 2016 trial ended in [[Mistrial (law)|mistrial]] after the jury became [[Hung jury|deadlocked]]. A [[New trial|retrial]] begun in May 2017 also ended in a hung jury. The charges against Tensing were later dismissed with prejudice.
==Backgrounds==
===Samuel DuBose=== Samuel "Sam" Vincent DuBose (March 12, 1972 – July 19, 2015), a 43-year-old black man, was a [[rapper]], [[music producer]], [[entrepreneur]], and motorcycle enthusiast. He was the founder of a motorcycle club, Ruthless Riders. He attended high school in Cincinnati and was the father of 13 children. Between 1995 and 2009 he was charged thirteen times for not having a license and four times for not having a proper license plate.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.wcpo.com/news/local-news/hamilton-county/cincinnati/hamilton-co-prosecutor-rapidly-investigating-uc-police-shooting# |title=Archived copy |access-date=May 26, 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160325062605/http://www.wcpo.com/news/local-news/hamilton-county/cincinnati/hamilton-co-prosecutor-rapidly-investigating-uc-police-shooting# |archive-date=March 25, 2016 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }}</ref> He also served less than a year in a state prison on a 2005 marijuana trafficking charge.<ref name=AP.Details>{{cite news |first=Andrew |last=Welsh-Huggins |title=Details on university police officer, shooting victim |date=July 29, 2015 |accessdate=January 21, 2016 |website=AP News |url=http://bigstory.ap.org/article/84b924e7068e484abaaa0459e0d41f11/details-university-police-officer-shooting-victim}}</ref><ref name="auto">{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2015/07/21/us/cincinnati-police-shooting/|title=Investigation finished in Cincinnati police shooting|publisher=[[CNN]]|date=July 29, 2015|accessdate=July 29, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.foxnews.com/us/2015/07/22/cincinnati-prosecutor-probing-shooting-motorist-by-university-police-officer/|title=Cincinnati Prosecutor Probing Shooting of Motorist by University Police Officer|publisher=[[Fox News Channel]]|date=July 22, 2015|accessdate=July 22, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.wcpo.com/news/local-news/hamilton-county/cincinnati/mount-auburn-shooting |title=Police describe struggle that led UC officer to shoot, kill man |website=[[WCPO-TV]] |location=Cincinnati, Ohio |date=July 19, 2015 |accessdate=August 3, 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150801005623/http://www.wcpo.com/news/local-news/hamilton-county/cincinnati/mount-auburn-shooting# |archive-date=August 1, 2015 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
===Raymond Tensing=== Raymond Tensing (born November 13, 1989),<ref name=Richinick/> a white police officer who was 25 years old at the time of the shooting, had four years of law enforcement experience. He joined the University of Cincinnati Police Department (UCPD) in April 2014,<ref name=AP.Details/> having previously been an officer with the department of [[Greenhills, Ohio]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://news.yahoo.com/latest-naacp-calls-policemans-indictment-encouraging-125225628.html |title=Fired Ohio cop used stun gun on man |publisher=[[Yahoo! News]] |agency=Associated Press |date=July 29, 2015 |accessdate=July 30, 2015}}</ref> He had left the [[Ohio State Highway Patrol]]'s training academy after attending for just one day. According to a highway patrol spokesman, he was unable to adapt to the physical and mental requirements.<ref name=Mura/>
Tensing graduated ''[[cum laude]]'' with a degree in [[Criminal justice#Academic discipline|criminal justice]] from [[University of Cincinnati Clermont College]] in 2012 and had a clean performance record.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.wcpo.com/news/local-news/hamilton-county/cincinnati/ray-tensing-sam-dubose-uc-officer-accused-of-killing-motorist-has-clean-performance-record |title=UC officer accused of killing motorist has clean performance record |website=[[WCPO-TV]] |location=Cincinnati, Ohio |date=July 29, 2015 |accessdate=July 30, 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150724202929/http://www.wcpo.com/news/local-news/hamilton-county/cincinnati/ray-tensing-sam-dubose-uc-officer-accused-of-killing-motorist-has-clean-performance-record# |archive-date=July 24, 2015 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }}</ref> He was involved in a fight in August 2010, a few weeks after he completed his training at the police academy. Tensing conducted an independent investigation of the incident, was described as being unhappy with the [[Cincinnati Police Department]]'s handling of the case, and was noted for his aggressive attitude at the time. As a result of his investigation, the case against other combatants was dismissed.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.wcpo.com/news/local-news/hamilton-county/cincinnati/ray-tensing-beaten-in-2010-fight-seemed-like-ticking-time-bomb-attorney-says |title=After being beaten in 2010 fight, Ray Tensing seemed like a 'ticking time bomb,' attorney says |website=[[WCPO-TV]] |location=Cincinnati, Ohio |date=August 5, 2015 |accessdate=August 6, 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150805220658/http://www.wcpo.com/news/local-news/hamilton-county/cincinnati/ray-tensing-beaten-in-2010-fight-seemed-like-ticking-time-bomb-attorney-says# |archive-date=August 5, 2015 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
===University of Cincinnati Police Department=== The University of Cincinnati Police Department is certified by the state of Ohio and has full police authority throughout the state. They focus their patrols areas on three campuses and the areas around them.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.uc.edu/publicsafety/about/police.html |title=Police |publisher=University of Cincinnati}}</ref> UCPD officers receive 616 hours of training at the police academy, plus 80 of rookie training, while city police officers spend 1,040 hours in training.<ref name=Mura/> Since the UCPD's patrol area was expanded to include neighboring areas in 2009, the number of reported crimes in those areas was cut in half by 2014.<ref name=Mura>{{cite news |last1=Mura |first1=John |last2=Stolberg |first2=Sheryl Gay |title=Samuel DuBose's Death in Cincinnati Points to Off-Campus Power of College Police |url=http://nyti.ms/1JWuoiH |accessdate=November 12, 2015 |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=July 31, 2015}}</ref> Officers increased their traffic stops on- and off-campus, tripling the number from 2012 to 2015.<ref name="cincinnati.com">{{cite news |url=http://www.cincinnati.com/story/news/2015/08/25/uc-cops-got-new-guns-dubose-shooting/32339335/ |title=UC police got new guns before DuBose shooting |date=August 25, 2015 |website=[[The Cincinnati Enquirer]]}}</ref> Of its 72 officers, 4 are African American and 1 is Asian American.<ref name=Mura/> Unlike the [[Cincinnati Police Department]] (CPD), the UCPD was not included in federally mandated reforms following the nearby [[Cincinnati riots of 2001|riots of 2001]] that had been in reaction to a shooting of a young black man by city police.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theatlantic.com/politics/archive/2015/07/samuel-dubose-local-police/399977/ |title=How One Campus Cop Undid a City's Police Reforms |first=David A. |last=Graham |date=July 30, 2015 |work=The Atlantic}}</ref><ref name=Mura/> One UCPD chief resigned in 2013 amid reported low morale, and he was not replaced immediately.<ref name=Mura/> Two other black men had been killed by UCPD officers, both with [[Taser]]s: a mental patient in 2010 and a student in 2011.<ref name=Mura/>
==Shooting==
At {{nowrap|6:30 p.m.}}, on Rice Street near Thill Street in the [[Mount Auburn Historic District|Mount Auburn]] district,<ref>{{cite news |title=Driver shot, killed by University of Cincinnati police officer in Mt. Auburn |date=July 20, 2015 |accessdate=August 5, 2015 |website=[[WLWT]] |location=Cincinnati, Ohio |url=http://www.wlwt.com/news/uc-police-officer-involved-in-mt-auburn-shooting/34246290}}</ref> Tensing was patrolling off-campus when he stopped DuBose for failure to display a front [[license plate]],<ref name=Coolidge>{{cite news |first=Sharon |last=Coolidge |first2=Kevin |last2=Grasha |first3=Dan |last3=Horn |url=http://www.cincinnati.com/story/news/2015/07/29/publish/30830777/ |title=Prosecutor: UC Officer 'purposefully killed' DuBose |website=[[The Cincinnati Enquirer]] |date=July 30, 2015 |accessdate=August 1, 2015}}</ref> which is a [[Primary enforcement|primary offense]] for [[Vehicle registration plates of Ohio|vehicles with Ohio license plates]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.cleveland.com/open/index.ssf/2015/08/ohio_senator_seeks_to_soften_f.html |date=August 13, 2015 |first=Jeremy |last=Pelzer |title=Ohio senator seeks to soften front license plate rule in wake of Cincinnati shooting |website=The Plain Dealer}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.cincinnati.com/story/news/local/2015/07/23/eliminating-front-license-plate-helped-shooting/30545935/ |first=Jessie |last=Balmert |title=Would eliminating front license plate have affected shooting case? |date=July 23, 2015 |website=[[The Cincinnati Enquirer]]}}</ref> The incident was recorded on Tensing's [[bodycam]], which he activated before the traffic stop.<ref name=Coolidge/>
{{external media | float = right | width = 25em | video1 = {{YouTube|id=992FY-hcUkM|title=Tensing's bodycam}} (27:25) | video2 = {{YouTube|id=FxXiniMalGA|title=Kidd's bodycam}} (27:27) | video3 = {{YouTube|id=CcYx2ML8DRg|title=Lindenschmidt's bodycam}} (8:58) }}
Seen in the bodycam video, Tensing repeatedly requests a driver's license and DuBose replies that he has a driver's license, then stating that he does not have it with him. Tensing asks, "Are you suspended?" Tensing starts to open the driver's door and orders DuBose to remove his seat belt. DuBose pulls the door closed, starts the engine, and puts the car in drive.<ref name=UC.Kroll/> Within the next few seconds, Tensing reaches into the car with his left hand, yells "Stop! Stop!", draws his pistol with his right hand, and fires once striking DuBose. Sources differed as to whether the car was moving before the shot was fired. According to the [[Shooting of Samuel DuBose#Kroll Report|Kroll Report]], "it is difficult to determine with precision how much, if at all, the car moved [prior to the gunshot], but whatever movement may have occurred appears to have been minimal."<ref name=UC.Kroll/>
After firing, Tensing falls away from the vehicle which accelerates as he and two other officers run after it. After travelling about {{convert|400|feet|m}}, the vehicle collided into a telephone pole and came to a stop.<ref name=UC.Kroll>{{cite web |url=http://www.uc.edu/content/dam/uc/publicsafety/docs/Reform/documents/Kroll%20Report%20of%20Investigation%208.31.2015.pdf |title=Review and Investigation of Officer Raymond M. Tensing's Use of Deadly Force on July 19, 2015: University of Cincinnati Police Department |publisher=University of Cincinnati |date=August 21, 2015 |accessdate=October 12, 2015}}</ref> After the officers reach the car, the video shows DuBose inside with a gunshot wound to his head.{{R|Perez-Pena|Richinick}}<ref>{{cite news |first=Greg |last=Noble |first2=Jason |last2=Law |url=http://www.wcpo.com/news/local-news/hamilton-county/cincinnati/watch-body-cam-video-released-in-sam-dubose-shooting |title=Body camera video released in Sam DuBose shooting |website=[[WCPO-TV]] |location=Cincinnati, Ohio |date=July 29, 2015 |accessdate=July 29, 2015}}</ref> The county [[coroner]]'s preliminary autopsy results, released on {{nowrap|July 31}}, confirmed that as the [[cause of death]].<ref>{{cite news |title=No Charges For 2 Cops At Scene Of Sam DuBose's Killing |date=July 31, 2015 |accessdate=August 1, 2015 |website=[[The Huffington Post]] |agency=Associated Press |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/no-charges-for-2-cops-at-scene-of-duboses-killing_55bbcd04e4b0b23e3ce2c9e2}}</ref>
In bodycam footage, Tensing repeatedly tells other officers that he was dragged when his arm became caught in the car, possibly in the steering wheel.<ref>{{cite news |first=Steve |last=Bittenbender |title=Ohio officer charged with murder pleads not guilty, released on bond |date=July 30, 2015 |accessdate=August 1, 2015 |agency=Reuters |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2015/07/30/us-usa-police-ohio-idUSKCN0Q31ZL20150730}}</ref><ref name=Perez-Pena>{{cite news |url=http://nyti.ms/1I23fN1 |title=University of Cincinnati Officer Indicted in Fatal Shooting of Driver |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=July 29, 2015 |accessdate=July 29, 2015 |first=Richard |last=Pérez-Peña}}</ref> In the police report that he filed after the incident, he stated that he was dragged, forcing him to fire his weapon. Through lawyers, he released a public statement that he was afraid that he would be run over.<ref name="Coolidge"/> On {{nowrap|July 29}}, authorities released Tensing's bodycam video, which, according to prosecutors, shows that Tensing was not dragged.<ref name=Perez-Pena/><ref name=Carrero-2>{{cite news|url=http://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/family-samuel-dubose-call-peace-after-officer-indictment-n400686|title=Family of Samuel DuBose, Killed by University Cop, Calls for Peace After Cincinnati Indictment|publisher=[[NBC News]]|date=July 29, 2015|accessdate=July 30, 2015|last=Carrero|first=Jacquellena}}</ref>
A day after the shooting, it was reported that DuBose was driving on an indefinitely suspended driver's license, and had four bags and a jar of marijuana and about $2,600 cash in the car.<ref name="Coolidge"/><ref>{{cite news |first=Katie |last=Rogers |title=Questions After Unarmed Ohio Man Is Killed in Traffic Stop |date=July 22, 2015 |accessdate=August 2, 2015 |website=[[The New York Times]] |url=http://nyti.ms/1Vv950s}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |first=Ben |last=Petracco |title=Search Warrant: Bags of marijuana found in Sam DuBose's car |date=August 5, 2015 |accessdate=October 14, 2016 |website=[[WLWT]] |location=Cincinnati, Ohio |url=http://www.wlwt.com/article/search-warrant-bags-of-marijuana-found-in-sam-dubose-s-car/3556692}}</ref>
===Investigation and police reports=== UCPD officers Phillip Kidd and David Lindenschmidt arrived at the scene just after the gunshot. In his bodycam video, Kidd is heard supporting Tensing's statement that he was dragged by the car. According to County Prosecutor [[Joe Deters]], neither officer stated in his official statement to Cincinnati police that he saw Tensing being dragged.<ref name=WaPo.NoCharges/> Officer-in-Training Lindenschmidt, who had started working in the field only that month, made what have been called "rookie mistakes" in picking up Tensing's fallen flashlight and moving Tensing's vehicle.<ref name=UC.Kroll/>
Eric Weibel, a UCPD officer who did not witness the shooting, stated in a report that Tensing's uniform looked like he had been dragged.<ref>{{cite news |title=Officers Involved In Samuel DuBose Shooting Were Sued In Earlier Death Of Unarmed Black Man |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/samuel-dubose-officers-sued_55baa370e4b0d4f33a023260 |date=July 31, 2015 |first=Michael |last=McLaughlin |website=[[The Huffington Post]] |accessdate=July 31, 2015 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160119052436/http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/samuel-dubose-officers-sued_us_55baa370e4b0d4f33a023260 |archivedate=January 19, 2016 |deadurl=no}}</ref>
The CPD took over the investigation soon after they were called to the scene.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Noble |first1=Greg |title=Sam Dubose, Ray Tensing: UC police officer said motorist was dragging him, so he shot him |url=http://www.wcpo.com/news/local-news/colleges/uc-news/sam-dubose-ray-tensing-uc-police-officer-said-motorist-was-dragging-him-so-he-shot-him |website=[[WCPO-TV]] |location=Cincinnati, Ohio |accessdate=November 16, 2016 |date=July 24, 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161030211046/http://www.wcpo.com/news/local-news/colleges/uc-news/sam-dubose-ray-tensing-uc-police-officer-said-motorist-was-dragging-him-so-he-shot-him# |archive-date=October 30, 2016 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
==Aftermath==
===Official reactions=== On {{nowrap|July 29}}, Hamilton County Prosecuting Attorney Joe Deters stated in a press conference that the shooting was "asinine" and "senseless". He said that DuBose was not acting violently or aggressively.<ref name=Ford>{{cite news |url=http://www.cnn.com/2015/07/29/us/ohio-sam-dubose-tensing-indictment/ |title=University cop indicted in traffic stop shooting |first=Dana |last=Ford |date=July 29, 2015 |publisher=CNN |accessdate=July 29, 2015}}</ref> With "an abundance of caution in anticipation" of Deters' announcement, the University of Cincinnati closed its Uptown and Medical campuses at {{nowrap|11:00 a.m.}} The campuses resumed normal operations the next day.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Ralston |first1=Michele |last2=Reilly |first2=M.B. |title=Information on July 19 Officer-Involved Shooting |url=http://www.uc.edu/officer-involved-shooting.html |publisher=University of Cincinnati |date=July 30, 2015 |accessdate=July 30, 2015}}</ref>
On {{nowrap|July 31}}, the [[Fraternal Order of Police]]{{en dash}}Ohio Labor Council, a union that represents UCPD employees, filed a grievance asking that Tensing be reinstated to his position on the police force, asserting that he was terminated "without just cause".<ref name=Saker>{{cite news |url=http://www.cincinnati.com/story/news/2015/07/31/tensing-union-demands-uc-job-back/30932331 |title=Tensing, through union, demands his UC job back |website=[[The Cincinnati Enquirer]] |date=July 31, 2015 |accessdate=August 1, 2015 |last=Saker |first=Anne}}</ref><ref name=McCormack>{{cite news |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/ray-tensing-cincinnati-police-union_55bba703e4b0d4f33a029a3a |title=Police Union Files Grievance To Get Ray Tensing His Job Back |work=[[The Huffington Post]] |date=July 31, 2015 |accessdate=August 1, 2015 |last=McCormack |first=Simon}}</ref> Resolution of the grievance is postponed pending the outcome of the criminal case.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.wcpo.com/news/local-news/colleges/uc-news/fop-ray-tensing-files-grievance-with-university-of-cincinnati-seeks-to-get-his-job-back |title=FOP: Ray Tensing files grievance with University of Cincinnati to get his job back |date=July 31, 2015 |first=Jesse |last=Folk |first2=Rose-Ann |last2=Aragon |website=[[WCPO-TV]] |location=Cincinnati, Ohio |access-date=October 23, 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151020054043/http://www.wcpo.com/news/local-news/colleges/uc-news/fop-ray-tensing-files-grievance-with-university-of-cincinnati-seeks-to-get-his-job-back# |archive-date=October 20, 2015 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
In the wake of the shooting, Deters called for the disbandment of the UCPD force and its replacement with city police officers. The incident also drew attention to the presence of armed law enforcement on college campuses.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.newsweek.com/indictment-cincinnati-campus-cop-raises-fears-about-armed-police-schools-360007|title=Cincinnati Indictment Raises Fears About Campus Police|work=Newsweek|date=August 5, 2015|accessdate=August 5, 2015|first=Max|last=Kutner}}</ref> There was some public and academic criticism of Deters' comments, on the basis that his rhetoric would jeopardize Tensing's right to a fair trial and that they were anti-police.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/nationworld/ct-ohio-fatal-shooting-samuel-dubose-20150807-story.html|title=Ohio prosecutor's comments in fatal traffic stop shooting of Sam DuBose draw critics|work=The Chicago Tribune|date=August 7, 2015|accessdate=August 7, 2015}}</ref>
The Chief of the CPD said that the memorandum of understanding, signed in 2009 by his predecessor, which allowed UCPD to patrol areas neighboring the university, should be revoked.<ref name=Mura/> He said, "I don't believe their officers have the skill set to police Cincinnati with the same philosophy of fairness and cultural competency that my officers display."<ref name=Mura/>
===Public reactions=== The body camera recording of Tensing shooting DuBose has garnered considerable attention. The footage has been compared to a [[First-person shooter|first-person-shooter]] video game<ref>{{cite news|last=Thomas|first=Dexter|title=Footage of police shooting of Sam DuBose in Cincinnati evokes disturbing video game|url=http://www.latimes.com/nation/nationnow/la-na-nn-dubose-shooting-footage-real-life-video-game-20150729-story.html|newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]]|accessdate=July 30, 2015|date=July 30, 2015}}</ref> and described as so "disturbing" that Cincinnati police prepared for large protests and riots before the footage's release.<ref>{{cite news|last=King|first=Shaun|title=The video of police killing of Sam Dubose is apparently so bad, Cincinnati is preparing for riots|url=http://www.dailykos.com/story/2015/07/28/1406408/-The-video-of-the-police-murder-of-Sam-Dubose-is-apparently-so-bad-Cincinnati-is-preparing-for-riots#|newspaper=[[The Daily Kos]]|accessdate=July 30, 2015|date=July 28, 2015}}</ref>
As of {{nowrap|July 30}}, at least four demonstrations have been held around the country in response to DuBose's death.<ref>{{cite news|title=At least 983 Black Lives Matter demonstrations have been held in the last 376 days|url=https://elephrame.com/textbook/protests|website=Elephrame|date=July 30, 2015|accessdate=July 30, 2015}}</ref> A [[Black Lives Matter]] vigil and rally in support of DuBose was held in Cincinnati on {{nowrap|July 31}}, the third such event since the shooting. The victim's mother said, "As long as we stand up for the righteous, we going to be OK. I would come out here every night, I will go city to city because now I'm involved, my child was involved." Participants chanted "I am Sam DuBose."<ref>{{cite news |url=http://wfin.com/sam-dubose-protests-in-cincinnati-lead-to-arrests/ |title=Sam DuBose Protests in Cincinnati Lead to Arrests |date=August 1, 2015 |publisher=WFIN |location=Findlay, Ohio |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151222161622/http://wfin.com/sam-dubose-protests-in-cincinnati-lead-to-arrests/ |archivedate=December 22, 2015 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> Around 300 participants subsequently walked through [[Over-the-Rhine]] to [[Fountain Square, Cincinnati|Fountain Square]]. Six people were arrested on charges of disorderly conduct and resisting arrest during the march.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://wlwt.com/news/several-people-arrested-at-fountain-square/34479936 |title=6 arrested in rally honoring Sam DuBose |website=[[WLWT]] |location=Cincinnati, Ohio |date=August 1, 2015 |accessdate=August 2, 2015}}</ref> One hundred protesters joined a "United March for Justice" on {{nowrap|September 19}}, linking DuBose's killing with the deaths of [[Tamir Rice]], [[Shooting of John Crawford III|John Crawford]], and Samantha Ramsey.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.fox19.com/story/30065478/dubose-family-leads-march-for-justice-saturday |title=DuBose family leads 'March for Justice' |first=Ashley |last=Harrington |date=September 18, 2015 |website=[[WXIX-TV]] |location=Newport, Kentucky}}</ref>
===Kroll Report=== A report, commonly called the "Kroll Report", released in September 2015 by [[Kroll Inc.]], a risk consulting firm hired by the university, said that Tensing's bodycam video showed that he was not dragged. It also said that the car had not moved, or had barely moved, before the gunshot was fired. It faulted both men for unnecessarily escalating the situation, DuBose by failing to comply with Tensing's command to get out of the car and starting the engine. The report offered no opinion as to Tensing's guilt or innocence in the criminal case. Tensing's attorney said, "I don't agree with their analysis or their conclusions."<ref>{{cite news |first=Dan |last=Horn |first2=Hannah |last2=Sparling |title=UC report: Sam DuBose shooting 'entirely preventable' |date=September 12, 2015 |accessdate=September 13, 2015 |website=[[The Cincinnati Enquirer]] |url=http://www.cincinnati.com/story/news/2015/09/11/uc-release-new-dubose-shooting-report/72058718/}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |first=Richard |last=Perez-Pena |title=Ohio: Report Says Killing by Officer Was Preventable |date=September 11, 2015 |accessdate=September 13, 2015 |website=[[The New York Times]] |url=http://nyti.ms/1i4X8ij}}</ref> The report's recommendations include reviewing the scope of the UCPD's jurisdiction, improving relevant training and policies, clarifying reporting requirements following officer-involved shootings, providing cultural diversity training, and assessing the diversity of officers within the UCPD.<ref name=UC.Kroll/>
===University reactions=== Following the shooting the UCPD stopped making off-campus traffic stops.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2015/sep/11/sam-dubose-shooting-independent-report |title=Samuel DuBose shooting was due to 'critical errors in judgment', report finds |date=September 11, 2015 |first=Ryan |last=Felton |website=The Guardian}}</ref>
On {{nowrap|October 16}}, a student group, named "Irate 8" for the eight percent of black students at University of Cincinnati campuses, presented a list of demands to the university president. The list includes taking officers Kidd and Lindenschmidt off patrol, conducting full background checks of police and other university employees, and mandating racial sensitivity training for all staff and students. President [[Santa J. Ono]] agreed to meet with them and discuss their demands.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.fox19.com/story/30273277/irate8-10-demands-to-uc|title=Irate8 to meet with UC president after giving list of 10 demands to UC |first=Brad |last=Hawley |date=October 15, 2015 |website=[[WXIX-TV]] |location=Newport, Kentucky}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.wlwt.com/news/irate-8-presents-list-of-demands-to-uc-officials/35866422 |title=Irate 8 presents list of demands to UC officials |date=October 23, 2015 |website=[[WLWT]] |location=Cincinnati, Ohio}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.wcpo.com/news/local-news/colleges/uc-news/irate8-student-group-issues-set-of-demands-to-university-of-cincinnati-leaders |title=Irate8 student group issues set of demands to University of Cincinnati leaders |website=[[WCPO-TV]] |location=Cincinnati, Ohio |access-date=October 22, 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151018164304/http://www.wcpo.com/news/local-news/colleges/uc-news/irate8-student-group-issues-set-of-demands-to-university-of-cincinnati-leaders# |archive-date=October 18, 2015 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
==Legal proceedings== {{wikinews|Ohio judge declares mistrial for officer who shot Samuel DuBose}} Kidd and Lindenschmidt were not indicted by the grand jury. "These officers have been truthful and honest about what happened and no charges are warranted," Deters said. Kidd and Lindenschmidt were placed on administrative leave during a university investigation.<ref name=WaPo.NoCharges>{{cite news |first=Mark |last=Berman |title=Prosecutor: No charges against other University of Cincinnati officers who witnessed shooting of Samuel DuBose |date=July 31, 2015 |accessdate=January 18, 2016 |website=[[The Washington Post]] |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/post-nation/wp/2015/07/31/prosecutor-no-charges-against-other-university-of-cincinnati-officers-who-witnessed-shooting-of-samuel-dubose/}}</ref><ref name=Carrero-3>{{cite news |url=http://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/body-cam-video-shows-uc-police-responding-sam-dubose-shooting-n401231 |title=Samuel DuBose Shooting: Second Body Cam Video Shows Police Response |website=[[NBC News]] |date=July 30, 2015 |accessdate=July 30, 2015 |last=Carrero |first=Jacquellena}}</ref>
On {{nowrap|July 29}}, 2015, Tensing was [[indicted]] on charges of murder and voluntary manslaughter. The murder charge carries a penalty of life imprisonment without the possibility of parole for 15 years.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.cincinnati.com/story/news/2015/07/30/tensing-arraignment-scheduled-thursday/30870405/ |title=$1 million bond set for officer charged with murder |website=[[The Cincinnati Enquirer]] |date=July 30, 2015 |accessdate=July 30, 2015}}</ref> As a result of the indictment, he was fired from the UCPD. At his {{nowrap|July 30}} [[arraignment]], he pleaded not guilty to the charges, and he was released on $1 million bond later that day.<ref name=Carrero>{{cite news |url=http://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/university-cincinnati-police-officer-indicted-murder-death-samuel-dubose-n400511 |title=University of Cincinnati Police Officer Indicted for Murder in Death of Samuel Dubose |last=Carrero |first=Jacquellena |date=July 29, 2015 |publisher=NBC News |accessdate=July 29, 2015}}</ref><ref name=Richinick>{{cite news |url=http://www.newsweek.com/grand-jury-indicts-officer-ray-tensing-shooting-death-samuel-dubose-358043 |title=Grand Jury Indicts Police Officer Ray Tensing for Shooting Death of Samuel Dubose |work=[[Newsweek]] |date=July 29, 2015 |accessdate=July 29, 2015 |last=Richinick |first=Michele}}</ref> A trial began on {{nowrap|October 31}}, 2016;<ref>{{cite news |title=2 Blacks, 10 Whites on Jury in Traffic Stop Police Shooting |date=October 31, 2016 |accessdate=November 1, 2016 |website=[[The New York Times]] |agency=Associated Press |url=https://www.nytimes.com/aponline/2016/10/31/us/ap-us-cincinnati-police-shooting.html}} {{Dead link|date=June 2017}}</ref> on {{nowrap|November 12}}, the judge declared a [[Mistrial (law)|mistrial]] after the jury became [[Hung jury|deadlocked]].<ref>{{cite news |first=Andy |last=Newman |title=Jury Deadlocks in Trial of Ex-Officer in Killing of Unarmed Black Driver in Cincinnati |date=November 12, 2016 |accessdate=November 12, 2016 |website=[[The New York Times]] |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/11/13/us/ray-tensing-samuel-dubose-trial-deadlock.html}}</ref> Ten days later the prosecution announced that they intended to retry Tensing, requesting a [[change of venue]] due to the amount of publicity surrounding the case in the Cincinnati area.<ref>{{cite news |title=Ex-Cop to Be Retried in Black Cincinnati Motorist's Killing |date=November 22, 2016 |accessdate=November 23, 2016 |website=[[The New York Times]] |agency=[[Reuters]] |url=https://www.nytimes.com/reuters/2016/11/22/us/22reuters-ohio-police.html}}</ref> A judge denied the change of venue, while extending a [[gag order]] in the case. A [[New trial|retrial]] was slated to begin on May 25, 2017.<ref>{{cite news |title=Gag Order for Retrial in Ohio Police Shooting |date=December 14, 2016 |accessdate=December 14, 2016 |website=[[The New York Times]] |agency=[[Associated Press]] |url=https://www.nytimes.com/aponline/2016/12/14/us/ap-us-cincinnati-police-shooting.html}} {{Dead link|date=June 2017}}</ref>. The presiding judge ruled that prosecutors could not present the T-shirt Tensing was wearing at the time of the shooting to the jury. The shirt depicted a Confederate battle flag, and the judge agreed with Tensing's defense that allowing the shirt as evidence would be prejudicial.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.cbsnews.com/news/ray-tensing-case-judge-rules-on-confederate-flag-t-shirt-in-officers-murder-retrial/ |title=Ray Tensing case: Judge rules on Confederate flag T-shirt in officer's murder retrial |publisher=Associated Press|location=Cincinnati, Ohio |date=May 26, 2017|accessdate=June 26, 2017}}</ref> On June 23, 2017, the second trial also ended in mistrial due to a deadlocked jury.<ref>{{cite news |first=Jess |last=Bidgood |first2=Richard |last2=Perez-Pena |title=Mistrial in Cincinnati Shooting as Officer Is Latest Not to Be Convicted |date=June 23, 2017 |accessdate=November 6, 2017 |website=[[The New York Times]] |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/06/23/us/raymond-tensing-samuel-dubose-cincinnati.html}}</ref> On July 18, 2017, Deters said he was dropping the case against Tensing, as two previous juries could not reach a unanimous agreement on murder and voluntary manslaughter charges.<ref>{{cite news |first=Dan |last=Sewell |title=Case Against Officer Who Killed Unarmed Motorist Is Dropped |date=July 18, 2017 |accessdate=November 6, 2017 |website=[[U.S. News & World Report]] |agency=Associated Press |url=https://www.usnews.com/news/us/articles/2017-07-18/prosecutor-to-announce-plans-in-fatal-ohio-police-shooting}}</ref>
Stew Mathews, Tensing's attorney, said that Tensing was being dragged by the car, and that the officer fired in self-defense while fearing for his life. Mathews said that video from Lindenschmidt's bodycam helped substantiate that claim.<ref name=Congedo>{{cite news |url=http://www.wlwt.com/news/uc-officer-ray-tensings-attorney-plans-to-use-selfdefense-claim/34433782 |title=Former UC Officer Ray Tensing's attorney plans to use self-defense claim |last=Congedo |first=Jackie |date=July 30, 2015 |website=[[WLWT]] |location=Cincinnati, Ohio |accessdate=July 30, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2015/jul/30/samuel-dubose-video-police-killing-cincinnati |title=Samuel DuBose video appears to show two officers reinforced false account of police killing |date=July 29, 2015 |accessdate=July 31, 2015}}</ref> However, video forensics expert and FBI instructor Grant Fredericks disagreed with these claims—testifying the video showed Tensing had never been dragged, and in fact pulled and aimed his gun at Dubose's head before the vehicle moved. Fredericks further testified he believed the vehicle's later acceleration occurred ''after'' the shooting, as a result of a "post-mortem reflex."<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.cincinnati.com/story/news/tensing/2016/11/03/what-expect-thursday-ray-tensing-murder-trial/93199114/ |title=Video expert: Ray Tensing was not dragged |website=[[The Cincinnati Enquirer]] |agency=Associated Press |date=November 3, 2016 |accessdate=June 27, 2017}}</ref> In January 2016, following two days of [[mediation]] with civil rights attorney [[Al Gerhardstein]], the University of Cincinnati agreed to pay $4.85 million to the DuBose family. In addition to financial compensation, the [[Settlement (litigation)|settlement]] included free [[undergraduate education]] for DuBose's children, the creation of a [[memorial]] in his name, an apology from the school's president, and engagement by the family in police reform at the university.<ref>{{cite news |first=Sheryl Gay |last=Stolberg |title=University of Cincinnati to Pay $4.85 Million to Family of Man Killed by Officer |date=January 18, 2016 |accessdate=January 18, 2016 |website=[[The New York Times]] |url=http://nyti.ms/1JVaavT}}</ref> It also protected all potential defendants from any future [[civil litigation]] in DuBose's death.<ref name=Cin.Settlement>{{cite news |first=Cameron |last=Knight |title=Settlement protects Tensing from civil suits |date=February 12, 2016 |accessdate=February 28, 2016 |website=[[The Cincinnati Enquirer]] |url=http://www.cincinnati.com/story/news/2016/02/12/dubose-family-file-civil-suit-against-tensing/80309672/}}</ref> On 23rd March 2018 Ray Tensing was awarded nearly $350,000 in compensation for unfair dismissal from his former employer.<ref>https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation-now/2018/03/23/settlement-ex-cop-ray-tensing-killed-sam-dubose/452121002/</ref>

{{Infobox caste|caste_name=Siviyar|classification=|languages=[[Tamil language|Tamil]]|religions=[[Hinduism]]|related=[[Konar (caste)| Idaiyar]], [[Tamils]], [[Sri Lankan Tamils]]|subdivisions=}}'''Siviyar''' ({{Lang-ta|சிவியார்|lit=Chiviyar}}, also written ''Chiviar'' and {{Lang-ta|சிவிகையார்|lit=Chivikaiyar}}) is a caste found in the [[India]]n state of [[Tamil Nadu]] and [[Sri Lanka]].<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.no/books?id=bfAMAQAAMAAJ&q=siviyar+tamil+nadu&dq=siviyar+tamil+nadu&hl=no&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwituujmhI_XAhVnD8AKHVHFAJUQ6AEIJzAA|title=Communities, Segments, Synonyms, Surnames and Titles|last=Singh|first=Kumar Suresh|date=1996|publisher=Anthropological Survey of India|year=|isbn=9780195633573|location=|pages=1130|language=en}}</ref> They were traditionally [[Litter (vehicle)|palanquin bearers]]. They are a single community in [[Sri Lanka]], but are however a subcaste of the [[Konar (caste)|Idaiyar]] caste of [[Tamil Nadu]].<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.no/books?id=QqXBTk_Ki1EC&q=siviyar+tamil&dq=siviyar+tamil&hl=no&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjKxt-vho_XAhXiK8AKHUmZAJIQ6AEINjAC|title=Casstes and Tribes of Southern India|last=Thupston|first=Edgar|date=1909|publisher=Government Press|year=|isbn=|location=|pages=391|language=en}}</ref>
== Etymology == [[File:Wooden Palanquin.JPG|thumb|A traditionally palanquin used in [[Jaffna Kingdom]]]] The name is derived from the [[Tamil language|Tamil]] word'' Civikai'' meaning "palanquin" and the suffix -ar denoting honorific plural.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=aG4LYJqJFKQC|title=Glossary of Native, Foreign, and Anglicized Words Commonly Used in Ceylon in Official Correspondence and Other Documents|last=|first=|date=1996|publisher=Asian Educational Services|year=|isbn=9788120612020|location=|pages=11|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=_f3_3gT_NmcC|title=Literary Techniques in Old Tamil Caṅkam Poetry: The Kuruntokai|last=Wilden|first=Eva|date=2006|publisher=Otto Harrassowitz Verlag|year=|isbn=9783447053358|location=|pages=101|language=en}}</ref> The headmen of them were known as ''Kūriyan'', meaning "proclaimer", in reference to his proclaiming or announcement of the titles of the person whom he carries before the palanquin.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=lxZCCegiccQC|title=Winslow's a Comprehensive Tamil and English Dictionary|last=Winslow|first=Miron|date=1989|publisher=Asian Educational Services|year=|isbn=9788120600003|location=|pages=352|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=WjgsAAAAYAAJ|title=An English and Tamil dictionary: or, Manual lexicon for schools. Giving in Tamil all important English words, and the use of many in phrases|last=Knight|first=Joseph|last2=Spaulding|first2=Levi|date=1844|publisher=American Mission Press|year=|isbn=|location=|pages=585|language=ta}}</ref>
== History == [[File:Seventy-two Specimens of Castes in India (47).jpg|thumb|Siviyars of India]] The Siviyars worked under the kings of [[Jaffna Kingdom]] as palanquin bearers, woodcutters and [[Water carrier|water carriers]].<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=qBZg0OhbiXMC|title=Asia in the Making of Europe|last=Lach|first=Donald Frederick|last2=Kley|first2=Edwin J. Van|date=1998|publisher=University of Chicago Press|year=|isbn=9780226467672|location=|pages=993|language=en}}</ref> After the fall of [[Jaffna Kingdom]], were the Siviyars under [[Dutch Ceylon]] serving as palanquin bearers under the Commanders and [[Dissava]]s, and were a powerful class in [[Jaffna]], who also held titles such as [[Ceylonese Mudaliyars|Mudaliyars]].<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.no/books?id=m2puAAAAMAAJ&q=chiviar&dq=chiviar&hl=no&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwio1Mubk4_XAhWMfFAKHfJ6AfIQ6AEIXjAI|title=Ceylon and the Dutch, 1600-1800: External Influences and Internal Change in Early Modern Sri Lanka|last=Arasaratnam|first=Sinnappah|date=1996-01-01|publisher=n Variorum|year=|isbn=9780860785798|location=|pages=384|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.no/books?id=_PSbAAAAMAAJ|title=The Laws and Customs of the Tamils of Jaffna|last=Tambiah|first=Henry Wijayakone|date=2001|publisher=Women's Education & Research Centre|year=|isbn=9789559261162|location=|pages=94|language=en}}</ref>
The Siviyars of [[Tamil Nadu]] migrated from [[Mysore (region)|Mysore region]] to Tamil Nadu during the reign of [[Tipu Sultan]].<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?hl=no&id=jHQMAQAAMAAJ|title=People of India: A - G.|last=|first=|date=1998|publisher=Oxford Univ. Press|year=|isbn=9780195633542|location=|pages=3305|language=en}}</ref>
Several from this caste were strongly represented in the [[Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam]].<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=fohqAAAAMAAJ|title=The Enigma of Ethnicity: An Analysis of Race in the Caribbean and the World|last=Premdas|first=Ralph R.|date=1993|publisher=University of the West Indies, School of Continuing Studies|year=|isbn=|location=|pages=297|language=en}}</ref>

'''Surveillance capitalism''' is a [[History of capitalism|novel]] market form and a specific logic of [[capitalism|capitalist]] accumulation that was first described in a 2014 essay by business theorist and social scientist [[Shoshana Zuboff]]. She characterized it as a "radically disembedded and extractive variant of information capitalism" based on the [[commodification]] of "reality" and its transformation into behavioral data for analysis and sales.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.faz.net/1.3152525|title=A Digital Declaration: Big Data as Surveillance Capitalism|last=Zuboff|first=Shoshana|date=15 September 2014|work=FAZ.NET|access-date=2018-08-28|language=de|issn=0174-4909|id=http://www.faz.net/aktuell/feuilleton/debatten/the-digital-debate/shoshan-zuboff-on-big-data-as-surveillance-capitalism-13152525.html}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Powles|first1=Julia|title=Google and Microsoft have made a pact to protect surveillance capitalism|url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/may/02/google-microsoft-pact-antitrust-surveillance-capitalism|publisher=The Guardian|accessdate=9 February 2017|date=2 May 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Sterling|first1=Bruce|title=Shoshanna Zuboff condemning Google "surveillance capitalism"|url=https://www.wired.com/beyond-the-beyond/2016/03/shoshanna-zuboff-condemning-google-surveillance-capitalism/|publisher=WIRED|date=March 2016}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/08/14/magazine/facebook-google-privacy-data.html|title=The Unlikely Activists Who Took On Silicon Valley — and Won|last=|first=|date=14 August 2018|work=New York Times|access-date=2018-08-28|language=en}}</ref>
In a subsequent 2015 scholarly article, Zuboff analyzed the societal implications of this [[Creative destruction|mutation]] of capitalism. She differentiated "surveillance assets", "surveillance capital", and "surveillance capitalism" and their dependence on a global architecture of computer mediation that she calls "Big Other", a distributed and largely uncontested new expression of power which constitutes hidden mechanisms of extraction, commodification, and control that threatens core values such as [[Free will|freedom]], [[democracy|democracy,]] and [[privacy]].<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Zuboff|first=Shoshana|date=4 April 2015|title=Big other: surveillance capitalism and the prospects of an information civilization|url=https://papers.ssrn.com/sol3/papers.cfm?abstract_id=2594754|journal=Journal of Information Technology|language=en|volume=30|issue=1|pages=75–89|doi=10.1057/jit.2015.5|issn=0268-3962|id=https://papers.ssrn.com/sol3/papers.cfm?abstract_id=2594754|via=SSRN}}</ref><ref name="theconversation1">{{cite web|url=https://theconversation.com/the-price-of-connection-surveillance-capitalism-64124|title=The price of connection: 'surveillance capitalism'|last1=Couldry|first1=Nick|date=23 September 2016|publisher=The Conversation|language=en}}</ref>
According to Zuboff, surveillance capitalism was pioneered at [[Google]] and later [[Facebook]], in much the same way that [[mass-production]] and managerial capitalism were pioneered at [[Ford]] and [[General Motors]] a century earlier, and has now become the dominant form of information capitalism.<ref name="faz1">{{cite web|url=http://www.faz.net/aktuell/feuilleton/debatten/the-digital-debate/shoshana-zuboff-secrets-of-surveillance-capitalism-14103616.html?printPagedArticle=true|title=Google as a Fortune Teller: The Secrets of Surveillance Capitalism|last1=Zuboff|first1=Shoshana|date=5 March 2016|website=|publisher=Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung|id=http://www.faz.net/aktuell/feuilleton/debatten/the-digital-debate/shoshana-zuboff-secrets-of-surveillance-capitalism-14103616.html?printPagedArticle=true|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=9 February 2017}}</ref>
In her Oxford University lecture published in 2016, Zuboff identified surveillance capitalism's mechanisms and practices, including the manufacture of "prediction products" for sale in new "behavioral futures markets". She introduced the concept "dispossession by [[surveillance]]" and argued that it challenges the psychological and political bases of [[Self-determination theory|self-determination]] as it concentrates rights in the surveillance regime. This is described as a "coup from above".<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.faz.net/1.4103616|title=Google as a Fortune Teller: The Secrets of Surveillance Capitalism|last=Zuboff|first=Shoshana|date=5 March 2016|work=FAZ.NET|access-date=2018-08-28|language=de|issn=0174-4909}}</ref>
==Background== Economic pressures of capitalism are driving the intensification of connection and monitoring online with spaces of social life becoming open to saturation by corporate actors, directed at the making of profit and/or the regulation of action.<ref name=theconversation1/> Relevantly, Turow writes that "centrality of [[corporate capitalism|corporate power]] is a direct reality at the very heart of the [[digital age]]". <ref name="theconversation1" /><ref>{{cite book|last1=Turow|first1=Joseph|title=The Daily You: How the New Advertising Industry Is Defining Your Identity and Your Worth|publisher=Yale University Press|isbn=0300165013|date= 10 January 2012|pages=256|url=https://books.google.com.au/books?id=m9_DyhPGhEMC&pg=PA17|accessdate=9 February 2017|language=en}}</ref>{{rp|17}} [[Capitalism]] has become focused on expanding the proportion of social life that is open to [[data collection]] and data processing.<ref name=theconversation1/> This may come with significant implications for vulnerability and control of society as well as for privacy. However, increased data collection may also have various advantages for individuals and society such as self-optimization ([[Quantified Self]]),<ref name=theconversation1/> societal optimizations (such as by [[smart cities]]) and new or optimized services (such as various Google applications). Still, collecting and processing data in the context of capitalism's core [[profit motive|profit-making motive]] might present an inherent danger.
Zuboff contrasts [[mass production]] of [[industrial capitalism]] with surveillance capitalism with the former being interdependent with its populations who were its consumers and employees and the latter preying on dependent populations who are neither its consumers nor its employees and largely ignorant of its procedures.<ref name=faz1/>
She notes that surveillance capitalism reaches beyond the conventional institutional terrain of the private firm and accumulates not only surveillance assets and capital, but also rights and operates without meaningful mechanisms of consent.<ref name=faz1/> Surveillance has been changing power structures in the information economy.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Galič|first1=Maša|last2=Timan|first2=Tjerk|last3=Koops|first3=Bert-Jaap|title=Bentham, Deleuze and Beyond: An Overview of Surveillance Theories from the Panopticon to Participation|journal=Philosophy & Technology|date=13 May 2016|doi=10.1007/s13347-016-0219-1|accessdate=}}</ref> This might present a further power shift beyond the nation-state and towards a form of [[corporatocracy]].{{citation needed|date=February 2017}}
[[Oliver Stone]], creator of the film ''[[Snowden (film)|Snowden]]'' pointed to the [[location-based game]] ''[[Pokémon Go]]'' as the "latest sign of the emerging phenomenon of surveillance capitalism".<ref>{{cite web|title=Comic-Con 2016: Marvel turns focus away from the Avengers, 'Game of Thrones' cosplay proposals, and more|url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/la-et-hc-comic-con-updates-oliver-stone-calls-pokemon-go-1469130980-htmlstory.html|publisher=Los Angeles Times|accessdate=9 February 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Oliver Stone Calls Pokémon Go "Totalitarian"|url=http://fortune.com/2016/07/23/oliver-stone-calls-pokemon-go-totalitarian/|publisher=Fortune|date=23 July 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=‘Surveillance capitalism, robot totalitarianism’: Oliver Stone lashes out at Pokemon Go|url=https://www.rt.com/usa/352782-pokemon-snowden-oliver-stone/|publisher=RT International|date=22 July 2016|language=en-EN}}</ref>
In 2014 Vincent Mosco referred to the marketing of information about customers and subscribers to advertisers ''surveillance capitalism'' and makes note of the [[surveillance state]] alongside it.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Mosco|first1=Vincent|title=To the Cloud: Big Data in a Turbulent World|publisher=Routledge|isbn=9781317250388|url=https://books.google.de/books?id=YwbvCgAAQBAJ&pg=PA10|accessdate=9 February 2017|language=en}}</ref> Christian Fuchs found that the surveillance state fuses with surveillance capitalism.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Fuchs|first1=Christian|title=Social Media: A Critical Introduction|publisher=SAGE|isbn=9781473987494|url=https://books.google.de/books?id=m3oEDgAAQBAJ&pg=PA204|accessdate=9 February 2017|language=en}}</ref> Similarly Zuboff informs that the issue is further complicated by highly invisible collaborative arrangements with state security apparatuses.<ref>{{cite web|title=Shoshana Zuboff / Keynote: Reality is the Next Big Thing - Elevate Festival 2014|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0QwPHinDdOc?t=12m30s|website=YouTube|accessdate=9 February 2017|date=2 May 2016}}</ref> According to Trebor Scholz, companies recruit people as informants for this type of capitalism.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Scholz|first1=Trebor|title=Uberworked and Underpaid: How Workers Are Disrupting the Digital Economy|publisher=John Wiley & Sons|isbn=9781509508181|url=https://books.google.de/books?id=LiDNDQAAQBAJ&pg=PT128|accessdate=9 February 2017|language=en}}</ref>
The term "surveillance capitalism" has also been used by [[Political economy|political economists]] [[John Bellamy Foster]] and [[Robert W. McChesney]], though with a different meaning. In an article published in ''[[Monthly Review]]'' in 2014, they apply it to describe the manifestation of the "insatiable need for data" of [[financialization]], which they explain is "the long-term growth speculation on financial assets relative to [[Gross domestic product|GDP]]" introduced in the United States by industry and government in the 1980s that evolved out of the [[Military–industrial complex|military-industrial complex]] and the [[advertising]] industry.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://monthlyreview.org/2014/07/01/surveillance-capitalism/|title=Surveillance Capitalism {{!}} John Bellamy Foster {{!}} Monthly Review|date=2014-07-01|work=Monthly Review|access-date=2018-02-12|language=en-US}}</ref>
==Key features== Zuboff identifies four key features in the logic of surveillance capitalism and explicitly follows the four key features identified by Google's chief economist, [[Hal Varian]]:<ref>{{cite web|last1=Danaher|first1=John|title=The Logic of Surveillance Capitalism|url=https://algocracy.wordpress.com/2016/03/21/the-logic-of-surveillance-capitalism/|website=Algocracy and the Transhumanist Project|accessdate=9 February 2017|date=21 March 2016}}</ref>{{Better source|reason=|date=February 2017}} <!--https://philosophicaldisquisitions.blogspot.de/2015/06/the-logic-of-surveillance-capitalism.html--> # The drive toward more and more data extraction and analysis. # The development of new contractual forms using computer-monitoring and automation. # The desire to personalize and customize the services offered to users of digital platforms. # The use of the technological infrastructure to carry out continual experiments on its users and consumers.
==Countermeasures and solutions== Numerous organizations have been struggling for [[free speech]] and [[privacy rights]] in the new surveillance capitalism<ref>{{cite web|last1=Foster|first1=John Bellamy|last2=McChesney|first2=Robert W.|title=Surveillance Capitalism by John Bellamy Foster|url=https://monthlyreview.org/2014/07/01/surveillance-capitalism/|publisher=Monthly Review|accessdate=9 February 2017|date=1 July 2014}}</ref> and various national governments have enacted [[privacy law]]s. It is also conceivable that new capabilities and uses for mass-surveillance require structural changes towards a new system to prevent misuse.
Zuboff compares demanding privacy from surveillance capitalists or lobbying for an end to commercial surveillance on the Internet to asking [[Henry Ford]] to make each [[Ford Model T|Model T]] by hand and states that such demands are existential threats that violate the basic mechanisms of the entity's survival.<ref name=faz1/>
Zuboff warns that principles of self-determination might forfeit due to "ignorance, learned helplessness, inattention, inconvenience, habituation, or drift" and states that "we tend to rely on mental models, vocabularies, and tools distilled from past catastrophes", referring to the twentieth century's [[totalitarian]] nightmares or the [[monopolistic]] predations of [[Gilded Age]] capitalism with countermeasures that have been developed to fight those earlier threats not being sufficient or even appropriate for the novel challenges.<ref name=faz1/>
She also poses the question: "will we be the masters of information, or will we be its slaves?" and states that "if the digital future is to be our home, then it is we who must make it so".<ref>{{cite web|last1=Zuboff|first1=Shoshana|title=Shoshana Zuboff: A Digital Declaration|url=http://www.faz.net/aktuell/feuilleton/debatten/the-digital-debate/shoshan-zuboff-on-big-data-as-surveillance-capitalism-13152525.html|publisher=Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung|accessdate=9 February 2017|date=15 September 2014}}</ref>

{{editorial|date=October 2016}} {{refimprove science|date=October 2016}} As part of their development into young adults, humans must develop an [[Identity (social science)|identity]] independent from their parents or family and a capacity for independent [[decision-making]].{{citation needed|date=October 2016}} They may experiment with different roles, behaviors, and ideologies as part of this process of developing an identity.{{citation needed|date=October 2016}} '''Teenage rebellion''' has been recognized within psychology as a set of behavioral traits that supersede class, culture, or race;{{citation needed|date=October 2016}} some psychologists, however, have disputed the universality of the phenomenon.{{citation needed|date=October 2016}}. According to [[Terror Management Theory]], the child's allegiance to parental authority and worldviews can weaken after the discovery that parents, like themselves and everyone else, are mortal. This unwelcome realization creates an unconscious need for security that is broader than what the parents alone provide. This can lead to new cultural allegiances, in the (sometimes flawed) search for a more enduring sense of meaning. The teenager seeks to perceive him or herself as a valued contributor to aspects of culture that more convincingly outlive or transcend the mortal individual's lifespan. However, since the parents also instill their cultural beliefs onto the child, if the child does not come to associate their parent's mortality with their cultural beliefs, the chances of rebellion decrease. <ref>https://www.researchgate.net/publication/289309102_Thirty_Years_of_Terror_Management_Theory</ref>
==Nature== There remains some debate as to whether the causes of teenage rebellion are completely natural or necessary. Some posit that an adolescent's failure to achieve a sense of identity can result in role confusion and an inability to choose a vocation, and/or that these pressures may develop from being viewed as adults.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://open.lib.umn.edu/intropsyc/chapter/6-3-adolescence-developing-independence-and-identity/|title=6.3 Adolescence: Developing Independence and Identity {{!}} Introduction to Psychology|website=open.lib.umn.edu|language=en-US|access-date=2017-11-30}}</ref> Indeed, in the Western world the age at which one is considered an adult (in both the cultural and legal sense) has advanced from the early teens in earlier centuries to the late teens – or even, in today's society, one's early twenties. However, simply focusing on contemporary western or western-influenced cultures, cannot answer the question of 'universality'. For example, if our hunter gatherer ancestors or historic agrarian cultures had different patterns of behaviour this would suggest that 'teenage rebellion' is not 'completely natural'.
In ''[[Scientific American]]'', however, Harvard psychologist [[Robert Epstein]] disparaged the notion of "the immature brain that supposedly causes teen problems" as largely a myth, and wrote that the turbulence often seen as typical of these years is not "a universal developmental phenomenon." Epstein alternatively contends that external factors – notably "[[Infantilization|treating older and older people as children]] while also [[Generation gap|isolating them from adults]] and passing laws to restrict their behavior" – are more likely responsible for the angst seen among many American teens.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.scientificamerican.com/article/the-myth-of-the-teen-brain-2007-06/ |title=The Myth of the Teen Brain |last=Epstein |first=Robert |date=June 1, 2007 |accessdate=May 31, 2016}}</ref> Likewise, in an article by Robin Lustig of [[BBC]], academic Cynthia Lightfoot states that what is now considered [[youth culture]] was created by the advent of compulsory formal education in the United States, due to the unprecedented separation of younger and older people that resulted from it. Lustig notes that the efflorescence of rebellious attitudes in teenagers of other countries has been concurrent with the introduction of Western culture into those countries.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/6209308.stm|title=Teen rebellion - a Western export?|last=Lustig|first=Robin|publisher=BBC|accessdate=February 19, 2017|date=2006-12-06}}</ref>
==The socioemotional network== [[Temple University]] [[psychologist]] [[Laurence Steinberg]] suggests that "stopping systems within the brain make adolescents more susceptible to engaging in risky or dangerous behavior."<ref>{{cite web |work=Temple University |date=April 12, 2007 |title=Teenage Risk-taking: Biological And Inevitable? |publisher=[[Science Daily]] |access-date=July 21, 2009 |url=https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2007/04/070412115231.htm}}</ref> He argues that social programs and measures discouraging youth from taking part in risky behavior (such as drug and alcohol abuse, reckless driving, and unsafe sex) have been largely ineffective.
Steinberg also posits that this is because teenage risk-taking is generated by competition between the socioemotional and cognitive-control networks. Both go through maturation processes during adolescence, but do so at different rates. Specifically, the socioemotional network, which dictates responses to social and emotional stimulation, develops more rapidly and earlier during puberty. The cognitive-control network, which imposes regulatory control over dangerous decision making, develops over a longer period of time, across the whole of adolescence.
Steinberg states in his article "Risk Taking in Adolescence: New Perspectives from Brain and Behavioral Science" that "systematic research does not support the stereotype of adolescents as irrational individuals who believe they are invulnerable and who are unaware, inattentive to, or unconcerned about the potential harms of risky behavior."<ref>Temple University (2007). Risk Taking in Adolescence: New Perspectives From Brain and Behavioral Science. Current Directions in Psychological Science pg. 55-59</ref>
Teenagers have the same ability as adults to evaluate risks and their own vulnerability to the risks.{{citation needed|date=October 2016}} Increased availability of information and education regarding the consequences of risky behavior have improved adolescents' understanding of the risks. It has done little, however, to change the actual behavior.{{citation needed|date=October 2016}}
This is because the rules that teenagers break when they rebel are based upon the logical system supported by the cognitive-control network.{{citation needed|date=October 2016}} This network is utilized by the adult authority, but is overthrown in adolescents by the stronger socioemotional network.{{citation needed|date=October 2016}} From the point of view of a cognitive psychologist, a large factor in teenage rebellion is the natural early development of the socioemotional network.{{citation needed|date=October 2016}}
A Cornell study from 2006 determined that teens are more likely to consider risk while making a decision, and for a longer period of time, than adults. They are more likely to overestimate the risks, in fact. Teens also, however, will take risks because they find the reward (such as instant gratification or peer acceptance) more valuable.<ref>{{cite web |work=Cornell University |date=December 12, 2006 |title=Why Teens Do Stupid Things |publisher=[[Science Daily]] |access-date=July 21, 2009 |url=https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2006/12/061211124302.htm}}</ref>
==Rebellion against peer norms== Not all teenage rebellion takes the form of violation of rules (i.e. illegal activity such as drug and alcohol abuse, vandalism, theft and other delinquency). Often teenage rebellion takes form in the violation of societal norms. And as these norms are set in place as much by teens themselves as by their adult caretakers, teenage rebellion within teenage culture is also commonplace. Rebecca Schraffenberger comments in her article "This Modern Goth (Explains Herself)" that her peers saw her bookishness and shyness "as vulnerability and ... made a game of preying upon it. I wasted a couple of years trying to conform and fit in, to wear the clothes from Benetton and buy the ultra-trendy Guess jeans. By the time I was fifteen, I gave up."<ref>Schraffenberger, Rebecca. (2007) "This Modern Goth (Explains Herself)", Goth Undead Subculture. New York: Duke UP, 2007.</ref>
In this case Schraffenberger abandoned the societal norms of Guess jeans for an alternative minority [[goth]] culture. Much of goth culture defies majority norms within the teen community; specifically it values fascination with subjects such as death, dark music, depression, and emotional demonstration, subjects which by nature are counter to societal norms.
==Popular culture== The phenomenon has been categorized by [[mainstream media]] and [[popular culture]],<ref>{{cite journal|author=Harris, Darryl. B. |year=1998 |title=The Logic of Black Urban Rebellions |journal=Journal of Black Studies |volume=28 |issue=3 |pages=368–385 |doi=10.1177/002193479802800306}}</ref> and is a very common subject in music and film.
==See also== * [[Generation gap]] * [[Positive adult development]]
==References== <references/>
==External links== * [https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2007/04/070412115231.htm Teenage Risk-taking: Biological And Inevitable?] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20110624025358/http://www.adviceandinfo.com/teenagers/ Parenting Teenagers]

{{Refimprove|date=August 2007}}
The''' Tula massacre''' was the title given to an incident near the municipality of [[Atotonilco de Tula]] in the [[Mexican state]] of [[Hidalgo State|Hidalgo]], north of [[Mexico City]], where 13 [[Colombia]]n men were murdered. The incident resulted in a minor political scandal, though no one was ever convicted of the crime.
==Background== On 14 January, 1981, the bodies of 13 men were found on the borders of a drainage canal in the [[Tula River]]. There was a doubt about the sexual identity of one of the victims, who could have been a woman dressed in men's clothing.
The bodies showed signs of extreme torture and mutilation, some of them with their heads still conserved in plastic bags. Some were decapitated, while others were slashed with machetes, and most with a shot to the head. The facts of what was to be known as the "Tula River Massacre" were denounced by [[J. Gonzales Gonzales]], who accused his boss, [[Arturo Durazo Moreno]], the then Mexico City police chief, of being the intellectual author of the ghastly crime. Moreno was the chief of police in Mexico City during the administration of his friend, President [[José López Portillo]].
The dead, apparently all Colombians, formed a band of criminals who were exploited by Moreno. Moreno allegedly hid them in jail and released them to rob banks repeatedly. It was said that Durazo decided to keep the loot and do away with the Colombians and their Mexican taxi driver, who also disappeared, last seen in June 1981 by his mother. It was said that the group were held in secret jails and the La Castaneda psychiatric hospital tortured and murdered them, and then dumped them into a sewer in Mexico City. Their decomposed remains were later fished out of the Tula River by a Red Cross diving team.
Moreno was considered{{by whom|date=May 2014}} to be corrupt, incompetent, and criminal. His friend, then President López Portillo, put up with it because they were childhood friends.{{Citation needed|date=November 2007}} Moreno fled Mexico in 1982 following the election of a new president and investigations into police corruption. He returned some time later and died in August 2001 in [[Acapulco, Guerrero]].
The pictures of the 13 dead and partial information of the crime was published by ''[[¡Alarma! (magazine)|¡Alarma!]]'', an explicit Mexico City publication that deals in images of dead, mutilated and deformed bodies.
==See also== *[[List of massacres in Mexico]]
==References== *{{cite news | first=George Byram | last=Lake | coauthors= | title=Fourteen murdered men haunt El Jefe - police corruption in Mexico City | date=1984-10-05 | publisher= | url =http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m1282/is_v36/ai_3465618 | work =[[National Review]] | pages = | accessdate = 2007-08-22 | language = }} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}

'''Vangala Eshwaraiah''', also spelt as '''V. Eswaraiah''' was the former chairperson, National commission for backward classes from 19.09.2013 to September 2016.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://indianexpress.com/article/india/india-news-india/appointment-of-ncsc-ncbc-chairpersons-by-year-end-thaawar-chand-gehlot|title=Appointment of NCSC, NCBC Chairpersons by year end: Thaawar Chand Gehlot|date=3 November 2016}}</ref> Prior to this appointment, he was Chief Justice of [[High Court of Andhra Pradesh]] in [[India]]. He was elevated to the constitutional post as additional [[Judge]] of Andhra Pradesh high court in 1999 and then as [[judge]] in 2000.<ref name="SCL 1">{{cite web|url=http://supremecourtcaselaw.com/jus_veswaraiah.htm |title=Hon |publisher=Supremecourtcaselaw.com |date= |accessdate=2012-07-09}}</ref> Government of India appointed Justice Vangala Eswaraiah, former Acting Chief Justice of Andhra Pradesh High Court as the Chairperson of the National Commission for Backward Classes (NCBC) on 23 September 2013.He was succeeded by Justice M. N. Rao, a retired Chief Justice of Himachal Pradesh High Court. - See more at: [http://www.ncbc.nic.in/User_Panel/EmployeeProfile.aspx?Value=ToHyC6Eu3vhfGxL%2BT%2B%2FsJENIQr7T6p9Cb9%2Bi2VKFs6o2rpSLWvDuzHTYKDSzLMYk View Profile:Justice V. Eswaraiah], Chairperson, National Commission for Backward Classes
He says in an interview to a journal as, we can only minimize but never eradicate crime no matter how many new laws are enacted unless people and the society mindset changes to respect the laws. The laws are not able to be effective as value for obedience, honesty and principles are getting diminished.<ref name="gic 1">{{cite web|url=http://goudsinfo.com/famous-Eswaraiah.htm |title=Suman Cine Hero |publisher=Goudsinfo.com |date= |accessdate=2012-07-09}}</ref>
He is influenced by [[Lekhraj Kripalani]], the founder of [[Brahma Kumaris World Spiritual University]]. During his visit to [[Institute of Sindhology]] in [[Sindh]] of [[Pakistan]], he called upon India and Pakistan to focus on universal peace, harmony and development of their people by curtailing defence budget on border tensions.<ref>he retired as acting chief justice high court of A.P. in march 2013,appointed as chairperson national commission for backward classes . Ministry of social justice govt of India from September 2013 to 2016 then working president lead India to ignite to mindsof student from fifth class of onwards APJ abdul kalam former president of India was mentor of the lead India movement .Now patron of jurist ,wing of brahma kumaries.They Committed for social justice submitted reports to the govt of India to subcategories the O.B.Cs,simplyfy the creamy layer , provide reservations in the private sector who got consesions allotment of the land from the govt , include in the central obc list based on the occupation of the income . (http://www.dawn.com/2005/10/14/local26.htm ]{{dead link|date=July 2012}}</ref>
==Professional career== He got married when he was in final year of Bachelor of Science([[Bachelor of Science|B.Sc]]) which he did from City College in Hyderabad. After marriage, his uncle encouraged him to do medicine which he could not write entrance exam due to the death of his family member.
He did his [[L.L.B]] from Law College of [[Osmania University]] in [[Hyderabad, India|Hyderabad]]. He enrolled as an advocate in 1978 and started working under his senior Talluri Dasharatha Ramaiah to handle cases related to excise. Right from 1980, he started his own practise to handle civil, criminal, service and constitutional matters in both [[high court]]s and [[civil court]]s in [[Hyderabad, India|Hyderabad]].<ref name="SCL 1"/>
He worked as government pleader from January 1990 till December 1994 for five years. He also worked as standing counsel for Andhra Pradesh Dairy Development Corporation Limited (A.P.D.D.C.L) and Nalgonda District Cooperative Central Bank. He was also advisor to Mother Teresa's Charity Secunderabad.
On May 17, 1999, he was appointed as additional judge of Andhra Pradesh high court. Later, he was appointed as judge of Andhra Pradesh high court on April 20, 2000 and still working as honourable judge.
From the date of his appointment he turned as a vegetarian and practicing continuously for spiritual elevation to keep up the oath taken at the time of the swearing as a Judge. He is the follower of Prajapitha Bramha Kumaris Ishwariya Vishwavidyala.
==Judgements== Through interim order, he stopped skyscraper project being constructed by Emaar Properties and Lanco Group owned by [[Rajagopal Lagadapati]] in plots belonging to [[Muslims]] [[Central Wakf Council, India|Wakf Boards]] erroneously and illegally allocated by [[Y. S. Rajasekhara Reddy|YSR]] government to his party [[Member of Parliament]] [[Rajagopal Lagadapati]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.indianexpress.com/news/andhra-hc-puts-lanco-skyscraper-on-hold/224038/ |title=Andhra HC puts Lanco skyscraper on hold |publisher=Indian Express |date=2007-10-04 |accessdate=2012-07-09}}</ref>
He prevented the exploitation of laws for political harassment on opposition political parties by ruling political parties by preventing police authorities from taking any coercive steps.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hindu.com/2005/11/30/stories/2005113007690300.htm |title=Andhra Pradesh / Hyderabad News : Police restrained in their action against TDP leaders |publisher=The Hindu |date=2005-11-30 |accessdate=2012-07-09}}</ref>
He directed the state government ruled by [[Indian National Congress]] (INC) to act in a fair and non-discriminatory manner by framing a uniform procedure when differential treatment biased on caste or religion towards employees caught by Anti Corruption Bureau (ACB) sleuths.
He decided that the writ petitions are maintainable on the letters addressed by the siting MLA Mr.Shankar Rao, about the fraud and corrupt activities committed by the EMMAR properties, its sister companies in view of the involvement of the larger public interest and also about the alleged ill-gotten money and illegal gratification invested in the companies floated by YS Jagan Mohan Reddy former MP and son of former Chief Minister YS Rajshekar Reddy, as a quid pro quo for the benefit confirmed on the invested companies by taking advantage of his father's position.<ref>{{cite web|author=M Sagar Kumar, TNN Oct 11, 2009, 12.12am IST |url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2009-10-11/hyderabad/28102581_1_acb-sleuths-bench-tribunal-for-disciplinary-proceedings |title=Act uniformly in ACB cases, HC tells govt |publisher=The Times of India |date=2009-10-11 |accessdate=2012-07-09}}</ref>
